Trevor, your project sounds very useful and I am interested in linking to=
 it from my homepage when it becomes available.  JNEAT is indeed out-of-dat=
e and in need of some major updating.  Also, a lot of people want to use JN=
EAT but are frustrated by its disorganization (although to Ugo Vierruci's c=
redit it was one of the first working alternatives to my C++ NEAT).  So it =
sounds like your project would address some real demand that is out there.
=

I'm also interested in the potential for a web-based interface for running=
 experiments.  That would be a great educational tool.

ken

--- In neat@ya=
hoogroups.com, Trevor Burton <worldofpaper@...> wrote:
>
> I recently asked=
 about C# and Java versions of NEAT.
> 
> I downloaded Ugo Vierucci's JNEAT=
 code, got it working and started having a
> nose through the source - it's=
 a bit of a mess and difficult to follow or
> adapt because of that. So i t=
hought i'd take a crack at refactoring it a
> little and that little has en=
ded up being a complete re-write. I've given it
> the rather imaginative ti=
tle of JNEAT2 - but this'll probably change when
> the right name suggests =
itself.
> 
> I'm not finished yet but thought i'd just post as i've been re=
ally enjoying
> this project and hopefully others will find it useful once =
i'm done.
> 
> Basically i've:
> 
> 
>    - Seperated the core NEAT classes=
 from the UI and the loading mechanism -
>    There's a nice easy way of cr=
eating new UI's to view the evolution/winners
>    etc. etc. now.
>    - Al=
l the properties are loaded via Spring's IOC container - so
>    everything=
 is in easy-to-read xml or properties files.
>    - Experiments are created=
 as JAR files - with all the spring context
>    files defining the experim=
ent's parameters/genomes/training data etc and
>    compiled .class files i=
nside - these are loaded by JNEAT2 and the experiment
>    can be executed =
- the settings can be adjusted and the experiment re-run or
>    saved back=
 out as a new JAR file so experiments can easily be transferred.
> 
> 
> I'=
m a Flash/Flex developer primarily so my interest in abstracting the UI
> e=
lements is so i can build a Flex client for this Java 'back-end' - this way=

> i can have a web-based interface for experiments.
> 
> This is purely a =
personal project at the moment - so i plan on releasing the
> finished code=
 as an open-source project and developing some experiments with
> it once i=
've got things working.
> 
> I'll keep the list updated with my progress an=
d if anyone has any
> comments/suggestions/requests feel free to drop me a =
line.
> 
> Regards
> 
> -- 
> Trevor Burton
> http://www.flashmonkey.org
> =
http://www.infrared5.com
>
